results.title: Japanese family
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation, Julien Bryan and William James
results.brief_description: The daily routine and activities of a post-war family of silk weavers who live in Kyoto, Japan. Illustrates work at the looms; preparation of meals; children doing school homework, visiting a park and watching a puppet show; and the preparations and observance of a Japanese New Year celebration by the entire family.

results.title: Japanese doll
results.brief_description: Describes the historical development of doll-making in Japan with a rich and colorful display of dolls of various designs. Also introduces the unique techniques of doll-making by one of Japan’s contemporary master artists.

results.title: Japanese boy: the story of Taro
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and William Deneen
results.brief_description: Uses the story of a Japanese boy, who learns the meaning of sacrifice, to reveal the attitudes, customs and problems of a farm family and to offer insights into the Japanese character. Suitable for primary level.

results.title: Japan: work and play in the land of the cherry blossom
results.brief_description: Brief look at varius aspects of Japanese life. Narration describing aspects of the culture is accompanied by footage of coastal villages involved in fishing and pearl harvesting followed by Tokyo urbanites attending flower shows and finally concluding with a description of geishas and footage of a geisha dance.

results.title: Japan: traditions & trends in the 80's - Yrs 9-12
results.brief_description: A generally informative program that gives an overview to Japan in four main areas: 1. Rituals and religion. 2.Economy. 3. Technology. 4. Policy for the People. Each segment could be viewed separately.

results.title: Japan: Tokyo to Taiwan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Ian Wright conducts this Lonely planet tour of Japan, experiencing the bullet train at 160 miles per hour, having his fortune read at a Buddhist shrine, visiting the peace museum in Nagasaki, and soaking up the fantastic environment at the Aso Fire Festival.

results.title: Japan: today and tomorrow
results.brief_description: Introducing Japan and showing the close relationship with Australia, which has developed over the last decade. Goods and industrial know-how are traded between the two countries - capital from Japan is used to develop our mineral resources while we supply her people with raw materials and food in ever increasing quantities.

results.title: Japan: the land, the people
results.brief_description: Describes how 83,000,000 people support themselves in a mountainous island nation, small in area, where arable land is extremely limited. The cultivaiton of rice, tea, silkworms and timber and the development of modern industries are shown, as well as Japan’s growth in the post World War II era.

results.title: Japan: The Island Empire
results.creator_credit: Maureen Zrike, Christopher Zrike and International Video Network
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Japan begins to unfold as you enter a Zen temple, then witness an ancient ritual in a Shinto shrine. In the resort of Ibusuki, you will marvel at guests buried to the neck in steaming volcanic sand. Admire the great Buddha of Kamakura and the splendid architecture of 400 year old Himeji Castle. Then plunge into the frantic pace of Tokyo during the Sanja Matsuri Festival.

results.title: Japan: the collective giant
results.creator_credit: Irwin Rosten, Gerald Renaud, Films Incorporated and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Japan: imperial power to industrial giant”.
Deals with management-employee relationships of Japanese corporations and the fact that this country has a highly productive labor force which has become a threat to other countries. Points out that industrial prosperity can bring mixed blessings such as transport problems and pollution.
